reasoning: The critique targets the post’s move from “more labor” to “more/smarter/faster labor,” especially the idea that researcher quality could multiply R&D speed a lot. That’s a meaningful support for the author’s case that compute is less bottlenecking than CES estimates suggest, but it’s not the whole case (the post also leans on experiment-efficiency gains, long-run reconfiguration/Jones-style arguments, extrapolation limits of CES, multiple R&D routes, etc.), so centrality is moderate. The critique offers a reasonable challenge (diminishing returns to intelligence; possibility that problem difficulty rises), but mostly as an assertion of uncertainty rather than an object-level refutation with specific mechanisms or quantitative constraints, so strength is limited. Several statements are overstated or somewhat straw-manning (e.g., “zero empirical evidence,” “treats intelligence as a magic wand,” “entire SIE thesis collapses” if the multiplier is small), reducing correctness. It is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little fluff beyond rhetorical framing.
title: Intelligence gains may not scale R&D output as dramatically as assumed
